caption.p: The challenges, failures, lessons learned and solutions from different countries in efforts to eliminate viral hepatitis

tr.td: High HCV prevalence, treated all patients and screening programmes were running behind, cost of diagnosis, number of PCR tests was a bottleneck

list-item.p: Before 2014: established data networking centre and political will to eliminate HCV. Since, 2016 pledge from the president to eliminate HCV [7]
National plan since 2014 including HCV treatment centres
Generic DAAs
Decentralising the screening project by using mobile units and different testing sites
Negotiated for a lower PCR price given number fo tests required
Loan from the World Bank and private sector cooperation
Companies helped to develop dried blood spot test
Simplify the monitoring strategy

tr.td: High HCV prevalence, need to identify the missing millions, reaching the younger population, cost, linkage to care

list-item.p: Integrated hepatitis care into HIV, TB and malaria care
Scaling-up advocacy for hepatitis, HIV and TB
Decentralisation of healthcare (screening and treatment) using primary healthcare
Massive screening programmes, focusing on affected age group of males (30–60 years) and high-risk groups
Universal screening in harm-reduction networks
Used medical university students as extra help in these harm-reduction networks
When elimination was feasible the authorities were on board
Strengthen the healthcare system through the support of Global Fund
More enrolment of public health specialists for linkage-to-care process

tr.td: Reaching the younger population, decline in number of people accessing treatment [18]

list-item.p: Decentralising care and bringing care to the community where patients access services (community care/primary care) [19]
Point-of-care test in needle and syringe programmes (RAPID-EC)
Increase awareness about new HCV treatments
Increase coordination between services, for example community and prisons
Support enhanced data management

tr.td: Prioritisation of treatment, high drug cost, high HCV prevalence and HCV transmission among PWIDs [20]

list-item.p: Established mathematical models to gain further insight into the best treatment strategies and harm-reduction programmes [21–23]
Price negotiations allowing the significant decrease in drug costs

tr.td: High HCV prevalence, optimising HCV in the VA

list-item.p: System redesign using LEAN methodology

tr.td: Linkage to care of the high-risk group, retention in care

list-item.p: Involving target group in establishing linkage-to-care strategies
Using affected community in building online and offline information platform [28]
Development of play-safe chemsex toolkit

tr.td: Projects stalled due to constant data gathering required by health authorities, screening programmes were successful but the labs could not process the numbers

list-item.p: Not everything has to be perfect

Negotiating is power, important to get all the major players in the room. The leadership must push the agenda forward; in addition, the industry must also understand the needs and can support the gaps in care

tr.td: Low general awareness and in key populations, rural areas hard to reach, low vaccine coverage

list-item.p: Aiming for high advocacy by increasing the political will
Decentralisation of healthcare
Government acknowledged viral hepatitis as a major health problem and sought funding
Strengthening of the programme by the Global Fund

tr.td: Small numbers of PWIDs accessed care, waiting lists for harm-reduction programmes are long

list-item.p: Established a fast-track intervention to seek-test-link-treat PWIDs [14,15]
Used previous HIV programmes as an example
Chain-referral sampling to engage individuals into care [17]
Rapid identification, fibroscans and biochemical testing all in a single visit
Peer-navigators to improve linkage to care

tr.td: Some actively injecting drug users remain difficult to engage in treatment and maintain on treatment; visitors from abroad, such as asylum seekers and foreign prisoners with pre-existing chronic HCV infections; patients at an increased risk of infection and re-infection (MSM, persons sharing needles)

list-item.p: Incentives (including financial) for difficult patients. Adherence support
Screening of immigrants and asylum seekers. Collaboration with the chief epidemiologist and immigration authorities.
Scale-up of HCV testing and harm-reduction efforts, including increased access to needles and syringes (NSP)
